author: Marc Bee
text: 'Food is fine
column5: but it is NOT dim sum. Also
column6: it‚Äôs pricy. Decor is very nice.'

author: Rachael Rohrig
text: 'This place is fantastic!! We hosted my sister‚Äôs baby shower here and had the whole place to ourselves which was wonderful. It is BYOB but their mocktails are so so good and you can always bring your own alcohol to make it a cocktail. All of the food was incredible: ham egg and cheese bao buns
column5: lox and cream cheese tea sandwiches
column7: dumplings‚Ä¶ all amazing! Highly recommend for any meal or an event!'

author: Dana Hansen
text: 'Have been wanting to try this place for a while and so happy we did! All of the food we tried was delicious. Our favorite was the General Tso Broccoli appetizer
column5: but we also ordered the fried chicken bao
column7: and the sesame chicken lo mein. Besides the delicious food
column8: the ambiance and decorations were beautiful. The staff and service was very good as well. Would definitely recommend to others & go back!'

author: Stephanie Vehon
text:
'We were excited to try this place and ended up disappointed. Some dishes such as the avocado roles and the coconut as crab rice lacked flavor.
The shrimp buns and soup dumplings were excellent. Thus the food is hit or miss.

Furthermore
column5: we were frustrated with the lack of service. When we asked for'

author: Ola Nesgovorov
text: "Very nice staff
column5:
the food is ready super fast & it's very tasty.
It's a fusion between American & thai style from what I tasted.
Lot's of greens & ginger notes.
I ordered the brunch omelette with sausage on the side
column7: and the portion is more than enough ."

author: Michael Song
text: 'Honey chicken bao bun with kimchi
column5: ube and begetarian dumplings were very good.  The ambiance and staff were amazing as well.  Will come here often.'

author: Ming Jia
text: 'What makes non-Asian people think they can open an overpriced
column5: mediocre dim sum place right next to an existing dim sum restaurant owned by people making authentic cuisine?'

author: Steven Lowell
text: "I went over to Hoboken via ferry from Manhattan to see a good friend of mine
column5:
who recommended this place. I absolutely loved it! Here's why!

1. The Basil Lemonade was incredible and so was the virgin bloody mary.

2. We had an incredible brunch and some of the freshest tasting pastries I have had in a long time.

3. Our waiter was a friendly young guy named TJ. He agreed to tell the chef to come out so we can tell him how much we liked the food.

The chef is this young
column6:
talented guy named Anthony Leonido who works at & partners with 4 other restaurants. Super friendly and willing to talk to us about the food he enjoys making.

Sunday Brunch ended about 3pm and they shut down for 2 hours and reopened for dinner at 5pm.

If you are just checking out the area or live in Hoboken
column7: I recommend this place because the chef is talented and seems very creative

author: Tae Kim
text: 'This is my first 1 star review. I went for brunch
column5: but it feels like I had an early dinner. All servers ignored me to order food
column6: so It took 15 minutes to order the food
column7: and although there were not many people
column8: I waited almost an hour for the food to come out. All the tables around me complained about the late food coming out
column9: but it was just an excuse without a word of apology.\nIn addition
column10: the bar code is required to view the menu
column11: but the actual price of the food was higher than that. After compiling
column12: manager showed me the paper menu and made an excuse that the menu price on the Internet was wrong.\nAlso
column13: if you look closely at Bill
column14: if you pay with a credit card
column15: a 3% fee is unilaterally made to the customer.\nA place I never want to visit again.'

author: Beverly Brown
text: 'Tragically this Dim Sum restaurant does not serve Dim Sum in the day time! The name of the restaurant is the English translation of Dim Sum
column5: which is traditionally served as breakfast or brunch.  Instead
column6: they only serve a standard American brunch in the day time
column7: which you can get anywhere. Typically Hoboken in that the facade looks great but the actual place has some ridiculous and disappointing  suburban twist. Food looks good
column8: but I will just head to much less expensive  place with excellent fare served at the traditional time.'

author: Max Nozewski
text: 'Amazing food. Great service.'

author: Nicholas Gkionis
text: 'This place is one of the best restaurants in Hoboken. The decor is beautiful and makes it perfect for a date night or dinner with friends. The food is served tapas style with american-chinese fare.  I liked the dumplings
column5: bao‚Äôs
column6: and the entrees. It is byob too which is always solid. Really really good. I highly recommend!'

author: Chloe Bergman-Ray
text: 'We had a good experience at Touch the Heart! The service was friendly and attentive
column5: and the food was overall quite good. Its also BYOB

author: Devin Seep
text: 'A unique cuisine restaurant to try if you‚Äôre ever in Hoboken. The food comes in a well balanced portion and is tasty as it sounds. If you‚Äôre a fan of buns as your appetizer try the hot honey chicken with kimchi on a bun it is very good! The American mix with Asian cuisine was a bit different but worth a try!'

author: Jessica P.
text: "We've had two great experiences at Touch the Heart!  The food is so delicious
column5: comes out very fast
column6: and is great to share.  The staff was kind and prompt.  The BBQ pork bao buns are our favorite!  Looking forward to going again."

author: Victoria Verdel
text: 'Great little place. Food was super yummy and came out quickly. Service was wonderful. Will be back for sure.'

author: chuck fitz
text: 'Food is great. Service is pitiful. How many times will you walk right by our table of four? Without even giving us a glance Chloe? 8pm. No dinner order yet. People we walked in with have their check and are paying.'

author: Dipesh Mittal
text: 'Hidden treasure! Asian American fusion food at it‚Äôs best. Would definitely visit again.'

author: Barb
text: 'Our new favorite in Hoboken'

author: Prashanth Reddy
text: 'Pretty cool spot. Cool ambience and tasty food.'

author: Jay Chua
text: 'Wasn‚Äôt impressed - thought it would be given the decor and ambiance but the food disappointed and the wait times were way too long‚Ä¶ perhaps teething problems as they navigate routines at the beginning'

author: Routie Assirbad
text: 'Horrible service
column5: slow and surf and turf today was soggy with too much eggs. Staff is unfriendly and food is not that great. Waiter forgot to bring out appetizer and then when we are leaving forced us to take it home and pay for it after we refused it. Horrible place. Management needs to train these employees to do a better job.'

author: Katie N
text: 'Went here on a rainy Saturday afternoon and this place was amazing. Service was extremely friendly and knowledgeable on the dishes
column5: and orders came out at the perfect time. The food was delicious- our favorite was the flower tea and buns. I will definitely be back!'

author: willzy34
text: 'Best fried rice I ever had.  Delicious mocktails are even better if you hand them a bottle of your favorite spirit to add to the drinks.'

author: Samantha Casternovia
text: 'The cutest place in Hoboken! The food is amazing and the atmosphere is beautiful.  Wasabi sweet potato dumplings alone are enough to have me coming back regularly. Look forward to them expanding into brunch! I only wish they had a sign so I would have gone in sooner :). Also please add vegan items so i can bring my friends!\nBut still 10/10'

author: Kesavan Menon
text: 'Fantastic food. Especially liked the Cheeseburger Dumplings but everything was great'

author: I And
text: 'Went there with my girlfriend and we shared the avocado egg rolls
column5: the fried plantain dumplings
column7: and the tofu bao buns. Everything was delicious and fresh tasting especially that California roll. The service was friendly and the ambiance inside was cute
column8: perfect for a quiet date night. Plenty of vegetarian options as well.'

author: Hana Sherza
text: 'Great food and quick service. Tried their chef special bao buns
column5: crab and coconut and beef lo mein. Everything was amazing! Also got same day reservations and they were taking in walkins too.'

author: Justin Grzeszczak
text: 'Great little spot in Hoboken. BYOB. The menu is shareable plates. The Bao Buns were really good.\n\nPlant vibes inside and some outdoor seating as well. A must try for small groups!'

author: Allison
text: 'I love this place! Very cute chill garden vibes
column5: food was very good and so was the service. It‚Äôs also not as well known so typically can find a table right away. I love that they are BYOB and make drinks with mock tails
column6: the tea selection is also unique. Positive experience and would recommend!'

author: Melissa Zoleta
text: "Super sweet staff
column5: pretty ambiance
column7: plus it's byob. Fried chicken baos and soup dumplings were my fave part of dinner.  Cute date/ girlfriends spot"

author: Chris Shimmin
text: 'The best thing about this place is the creativity and design. The dishes
column5: atmosphere
column7: are all beautiful.\n\nAs for the food flavors
column8: nothing really stuck out. Also I thought the dishes were a bit pricey.'

author: Oscar Vargas
text:
'Mongolian Beef Rag√∫ and Asian Garden Mac & cheese.

Enough said.

Perfect date spot.'

author: Parvathy Ajit
text: 'Amazing Ambience and Service! A bit more attention needed for the tastes & flavors.'

author: Dhananjay Salgaocar
text: "Food was okay not great. The fusion concept didn't work for a lot of the dishes. Portions are measly
column5: even for dishes with not so premium meat."

author: Megan Gillen
text: 'Went here for dinner and enjoyed it! Definitely a modern/fusion Asian American place but I liked the food. Most notable was their take on soup dumplings- the broth was served in a shot glass! The overall atmosphere and aesthetic is also very instagrammable
column5: complete with a plants lining the walls and also available to purchase.'

author: Sunpyo Hong
text: 'Definitely disappointing. The food is not Chinese-American. Flavors are for people that are uncomfortable trying new things. Portion sizes are laughable for the price you pay. Would not recommend.'

author: Lyla Mannoia
text: 'I went with a handful of friends
column5: we brought our own wine and we just ordered a variety of things from the menu. The five of us sat outside under the canopy and the lighting
column6: table setting and ambiance was so pretty.\n\nI am still thinking of the delicious lotus roots and green beans that we had! The shrimp spring rolls were good. The eggplant lo mein was delicious. I loved that there were a number of vegetarian options and the dishes were made to share. I wish I had taken pictures of the dishes
column7: but when they came out they looked so yummy that we all just dug right in. üò¨\n\nCan‚Äôt wait to go back and try the rest of their menu items! They were out of the bok choy
column8: but I‚Äôll be back for those! We had a great time! Thank you!'

author: Gil Johnson
text: 'The staff was extremely nice and the food was good. Couldn‚Äôt have asked for better.'

author: Liza Gomelski
text: 'I couldn‚Äôt give a 2.5 so I‚Äôm giving a 3. Honestly
column5: I didn‚Äôt hate anything
column6: but I didn‚Äôt really like anything either. We were seated outside on the far end near the frame shop and no one came to take our order for what felt like substantial amount of time. That being said
column7: our waitress was very nice and apologetic. She really was not the problem. We arrived at 7:50 put our order in around 8‚Äôish
column10: cucumbers) didn‚Äôt come out until 9.\n\nIt is BYOB with option to use their mixes. We brought tequila and used their ‚Äújust add tequila‚Äù mix. I liked it
column12: my boyfriend did not like it at all. I think a bit steep for $8/glass for my own tequila.\n\nWe ordered: spicy cucumber
column14: Dan Dan noodles (the noodles were not noodles and in fact 1.5‚Äù long ‚Äúnoodles‚Äù. The way you cut up food for your toddler and difficult to eat with a chopstick or fork)
column15: the fried chicken boa (which was the best thing)
column16: and soup dumplings.\n\nThis place is brand new and I understand that every restaurant needs to work out its kinks. I will try It again in the future but was extremely unsatisfied with the timing and flavor of food. Did not leave a good first impression. I hope management can work out the timing from the kitchen.'
